articles.title: Shishir's Website
articles.description: Some additional details about the website
articles.contents:
Here is my visualizations:
The FIFA22 dataset contains all key attributes, and features of male
football players around the world. In this analysis, I focus on major
attributes to see relationship between common variables such as;
Potential & wages.
Reputation & Value.
Reputation and wages
Height and potential.
I also answer questions such as; what are the height, wage, weight
and age distribution of players? What is the prevalent foot amount
players? What are the countries with the highest representation in the
data? What are the most common player position? Who are the highest paid
players? Who are the best players overall?












I want
to group player earnings based on their work rate






























table(FIFA_22_Mens_Players_Data$nationality_name)
sort(table(FIFA_22_Mens_Players_Data$nationality_name), decreasing = TRUE)[1:3] 
ggplot(FIFA_22_Mens_Players_Data, aes(x=nationality_name))+geom_bar()

ggplot(FIFA_22_Mens_Players_Data, aes(x=player_positions))+geom_bar()+options(axis.text.x = theme_text(angle=90))















z





mapping: x = ~defending 
geom_density: na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA, outline.type = upper
stat_density: na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA
position_identity 




table(FIFA_22_Mens_Players_Data$league_name,FIFA_22_Mens_Players_Data$wage_eur))
ggplot(FIFA_22_Mens_Players_Data, aes(x=wage_eur, pace)+geom_col(aes(colour=international_reputation))
[mydata$sex=="M",c("person","age","funny","age.mon")]
library(ggmap)
library(dplyr)
help("get_map")
mapdata <- map_data("world")

View(mapdata)
colnames(FIFA_22_Mens_Players_Data)[colnames(FIFA_22_Mens_Players_Data)=="nationality_name"]<-"region"

mapdata<-left_join(mapdata, FIFA_22_Mens_Players_Data, by = "region")
View(mapdata)
mapdata1<- filter(mapdata, !is.na(mapdata$sofifa_id))
View(mapdata1)
worldmap <- ggplot(world, aes(x=long, y=lat, group=group)) +
geom_path() + scale_y_continuous(breaks=(-2:2) * 30) +
scale_x_continuous(breaks=(-4:4) * 45)
#this works worldmap + geom_point(aes(50, 30, colour=“red”))
#world.map<- get_map(“World”, zoom =)
p = ggplot() +
    geom_map(
      data = map, map = map,
      aes(long, , map_id = region),
      alpha=0.7
    ) +
    geom_point(data=FIFA_22_Mens_Players_Data, 
               aes(long, lat,
                   size=people_partially_vaccinated,
                   color=country_region),
               alpha = 0.6) +
    scale_size(range=c(1, 6)) +
    labs(size="Partially\nVacc Rate") +
    scale_colour_discrete(guide = "none") +
    labs(title = 'COVID-19 Partial Vaccination Rate\n
         Date: {frame_time}') +
    transition_time(date) +
    ease_aes('elastic-in')
    
animate(p, fps=4)

articles.title: My Website: Shishir
articles.description: Welcome to the website. I hope you enjoy it!
articles.contents:
My Website
          
          
          
          
          Semester project
           
          ▾
          
          
          About Me
          FIFA DATA ANALYSIS
          My Visualizations
          
          
          ☰
          
          
      
        
          
            
          
            My Website: Shishir
          
          
            
          
          
            This is the website for Shishir Katta.
            I am a student at Bucknell University in Lewisburg,
            Pennsylvanian. I am a Psychology major, with minors in
            Statistics and Economics. I am International student who was
            born and brought up in Bangalore, India.
            library(distill)
library(postcards)
            create_article(file = “about”, # Future name of the .Rmd
            file template = “onofre”, # name of the template package =
            “postcards”) # package that includes the template

            package = “postcards”) # package that includes the template

            .Rmd file template = “onofre”, # name of the template
            package = “postcards”) # package that includes the

articles.contents:

Generative art!



Note that the author recommends saving your artwork to a file since
it will often take a lot of time and RAM to render in RStudio. e.g.
